objects.description:
# Data Compressed

* Tactic
	* Exfiltration
* Requires Network
	* No
* Platform
	* Linux
	* macOS
	* Windows
* Data Sources
	* File monitoring
	* Binary file metadata
	* Process command line parameters
	* Process monitoring

# Examples

* APT1 has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.
* APT3 has used tools to compress data before exfilling it. 
* BRONZE BUTLER has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.
* CopyKittens uses ZPP, a .NET console program, to compress files with ZIP.
* Following data collection, FIN6 has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.
* FIN8 has used RAR to compress collected data before .
* The Ke3chang group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.
* Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server.
* Sowbug extracted documents and bundled them into a RAR archive.
* Threat Group-3390 has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.
* menuPass has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.


# Description

An adversary may compress data (e.g., sensitive documents) that is collected prior to exfiltration in order to make it portable and minimize the amount of data sent over the network. The compression is done separately from the exfiltration channel and is performed using a custom program or algorithm, or a more common compression library or utility such as 7zip, RAR, ZIP, or zlib.

# Detection

Compression software and compressed files can be detected in many ways. Common utilities that may be present on the system or brought in by an adversary may be detectable through process monitoring and monitoring for command-line arguments for known compression utilities. This may yield a significant amount of benign events, depending on how systems in the environment are typically used.

If the communications channel is unencrypted, compressed files can be detected in transit during exfiltration with a network intrusion detection or data loss prevention system analyzing file headers.

# Mitigation

Identify unnecessary system utilities, third-party tools, or potentially malicious software that may be used to compress files, and audit and/or block them by using whitelisting tools, like AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.

If network intrusion prevention or data loss prevention tools are set to block specific file types from leaving the network over unencrypted channels, then an adversary may move to an encrypted channel.

# References

* [Wikipedia File Header Signatures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List%20of%20file%20signatures)
* [Beechey 2010](http://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/application/application-whitelisting-panacea-propaganda-33599)
* [Windows Commands JPCERT](http://blog.jpcert.or.jp/2016/01/windows-commands-abused-by-attackers.html)
* [NSA MS AppLocker](https://www.iad.gov/iad/library/ia-guidance/tech-briefs/application-whitelisting-using-microsoft-applocker.cfm)
* [Corio 2008](http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/2008.06.srp.aspx)
* [TechNet Applocker vs SRP](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee791851.aspx)


# Platforms

* Linux 

* macOS 

* Windows

# Data Encoding

* Tactic
	* Command and control
* Requires Network
	* Yes
* Platform
	* Linux
	* macOS
	* Windows
* Permissions Required
	* User
* Data Sources
	* Packet capture
	* Process use of network
	* Process Monitoring
	* Network protocol analysis

# Examples

* Several BRONZE BUTLER tools encode data with base64 when posting it to a C2 server.
* A Lazarus Group malware sample encodes data with base64.
* Patchwork used Base64 to encode C2 traffic.


# Description

Command and control (C2) information is encoded using a standard data encoding system. Use of data encoding may be to adhere to existing protocol specifications and includes use of ASCII, Unicode, Base64,  MIME, UTF-8, or other binary-to-text and character encoding systems. Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.

# Detection

Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect communications that do not follow the expected protocol behavior for the port that is being used.

# Mitigation

Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

# References

* [Wikipedia Binary-to-text Encoding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary-to-text%20encoding)
* [Wikipedia Character Encoding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Character%20encoding)

# Examples

* BRONZE BUTLER has compressed and encrypted data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.
* CopyKittens encrypts data with a substitute cipher prior to exfiltration.
* TRINITY malware used by FIN6 encodes data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the OxAA key.
* Ke3chang is known to use RAR with passwords to encrypt data prior to exfiltration.
* Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server.Lazarus Group malware sample encrypts data using a simple byte based XOR operation prior to exfiltration.
* Threat Group-3390 has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.


# Description

Data is encrypted before being exfiltrated in order to hide the information that is being exfiltrated from detection or to make the exfiltration less conspicuous upon inspection by a defender. The encryption is performed by a utility, programming library, or custom algorithm on the data itself and is considered separate from any encryption performed by the command and control or file transfer protocol. Common file archive formats that can encrypt files are RAR and zip.

Other exfiltration techniques likely apply as well to transfer the information out of the network, such as Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel and Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

# Detection

Encryption software and encrypted files can be detected in many ways. Common utilities that may be present on the system or brought in by an adversary may be detectable through process monitoring and monitoring for command-line arguments for known encryption utilities. This may yield a significant amount of benign events, depending on how systems in the environment are typically used. Often the encryption key is stated within command-line invocation of the software. 

A process that loads the Windows DLL crypt32.dll may be used to perform encryption, decryption, or verification of file signatures. 

Network traffic may also be analyzed for entropy to determine if encrypted data is being transmitted. If the communications channel is unencrypted, encrypted files of known file types can be detected in transit during exfiltration with a network intrusion detection or data loss prevention system analyzing file headers.

# Mitigation

Identify unnecessary system utilities, third-party tools, or potentially malicious software that may be used to encrypt files, and audit and/or block them by using whitelisting tools, like AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.

# References

* [Zhang 2013](http://www.netsec.colostate.edu/~zhang/DetectingEncryptedBotnetTraffic.pdf)
* [Wikipedia File Header Signatures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List%20of%20file%20signatures)
* [Beechey 2010](http://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/application/application-whitelisting-panacea-propaganda-33599)
* [Windows Commands JPCERT](http://blog.jpcert.or.jp/2016/01/windows-commands-abused-by-attackers.html)
* [NSA MS AppLocker](https://www.iad.gov/iad/library/ia-guidance/tech-briefs/application-whitelisting-using-microsoft-applocker.cfm)
* [Corio 2008](http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/2008.06.srp.aspx)
* [TechNet Applocker vs SRP](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee791851.aspx)


# Platforms

* Linux 

* macOS 

* Windows

objects.description:
# Data Obfuscation

* Tactic
	* Command and control
* Requires Network
	* Yes
* Platform
	* Linux
	* macOS
	* Windows
* Data Sources
	* Packet capture
	* Process use of network
	* Process monitoring
	* Network protocol analysis

# Examples

* APT28 added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.
* The Axiom group has used other forms of obfuscation, include commingling legitimate traffic with communications traffic so that network streams appear legitimate. Some malware that has been used by Axiom also uses steganography to hide communication in PNG image files.


# Description

Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, commingling legitimate traffic with C2 communications traffic, or using a non-standard data encoding system, such as a modified Base64 encoding for the message body of an HTTP request.

# Detection

Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect communications that do not follow the expected protocol behavior for the port that is being used.

# Mitigation

Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

# References

* [University of Birmingham C2](https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1408/1408.1136.pdf)
* [University of Birmingham C2](https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1408/1408.1136.pdf)


# Platforms

* Linux 

* macOS 

* Windows

objects.description: # Data Staged * Tactic * Collection * Platform * Linux * macOS * Windows * Data Sources * File monitoring * Process monitoring * Process command line parameters # Examples * APT28 has stored captured credential information in a file named pi.log. * APT3 has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location. * FIN5 scripts save memory dump data into a specific directory on hosts in the victim environment. * TRINITY malware used by FIN6 identifies payment card track data on the victim and then copies it to a local file in a subdirectory of C:\Windows\. Once the malware collects the data, FIN6 actors compressed data and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration. * FIN8 aggregates staged data from a network into a single location. * Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is saved in the %TEMP% directory, then compressed, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. * Leviathan has used C:\Windows\Debug and C:\Perflogs as staging directories. * Threat Group-3390 has staged encrypted archives for exfiltration on Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with China Chopper. * menuPass stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin. # Description Collected data is staged in a central location or directory prior to Exfiltration. Data may be kept in separate files or combined into one file through techniques such as Data Compressed or Data Encrypted. Interactive command shells may be used, and common functionality within cmd and bash may be used to copy data into a staging location. # Detection Processes that appear to be reading files from disparate locations and writing them to the same directory or file may be an indication of data being staged, especially if they are suspected of performing encryption or compression on the files. Monitor processes and command-line arguments for actions that could be taken to collect and combine files. Remote access tools with built-in features may interact directly with the Windows API to gather and copy to a location. Data may also be acquired and staged through Windows system management tools such as Windows Management Instrumentation and PowerShell. # Mitigation Identify unnecessary system utilities or potentially malicious software that may be used to collect data from removable media, and audit and/or block them by using whitelisting tools, like AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate. # References * [Beechey 2010](http://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/application/application-whitelisting-panacea-propaganda-33599) * [Windows Commands JPCERT](http://blog.jpcert.or.jp/2016/01/windows-commands-abused-by-attackers.html) * [NSA MS AppLocker](https://www.iad.gov/iad/library/ia-guidance/tech-briefs/application-whitelisting-using-microsoft-applocker.cfm) * [Corio 2008](http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/2008.06.srp.aspx) * [TechNet Applocker vs SRP](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee791851.aspx) # Platforms * Linux * macOS * Windows

# Data Transfer Size Limits

* Tactic
	* Exfiltration
* Requires Network
	* Yes
* Platform
	* Linux
	* macOS
	* Windows
* Data Sources
	* Packet capture
	* Netflow/Enclave netflow
	* Process use of network
	* Process monitoring

# Examples

* Threat Group-3390 actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.


# Description

An adversary may exfiltrate data in fixed size chunks instead of whole files or limit packet sizes below certain thresholds. This approach may be used to avoid triggering network data transfer threshold alerts.

# Detection

Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). If a process maintains a long connection during which it consistently sends fixed size data packets or a process opens connections and sends fixed sized data packets at regular intervals, it may be performing an aggregate data transfer. Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect communications that do not follow the expected protocol behavior for the port that is being used.

# Mitigation

Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool command and control signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

# References

* [University of Birmingham C2](https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1408/1408.1136.pdf)
* [University of Birmingham C2](https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1408/1408.1136.pdf)


# Platforms

* Linux 

* macOS 

* Windows

objects.description:
# Data from Information Repositories

* Tactic
	* Collection
* Platform
	* Linux
	* Windows
	* macOS
* Permissions Required
	* User
* Data Sources
	* Application Logs
	* Authentication logs
	* Data loss prevention
	* Third party application logs

# Examples

* APT28 has collected information from Microsoft SharePoint services within target networks.


# Description

Adversaries may leverage information repositories to mine valuable information. Information repositories are tools that allow for storage of information, typically to facilitate collaboration or information sharing between users, and can store a wide variety of data that may aid adversaries in further objectives, or direct access to the target information.

The following is a brief list of example information that may hold potential value to an adversary and may also be found on an information repository:

* Policies, procedures, and standards
* Physical / logical network diagrams
* System architecture diagrams
* Technical system documentation
* Testing / development credentials
* Work / project schedules
* Source code snippets
* Links to network shares and other internal resources

Common information repositories:

## Microsoft SharePoint
Found in many enterprise networks and often used to store and share significant amounts of documentation.

## Atlassian Confluence
Often found in development environments alongside Atlassian JIRA, Confluence is generally used to store development-related documentation.

# Detection

As information repositories generally have a considerably large user base, detection of malicious use can be non-trivial. At minimum, access to information repositories performed by privileged users (for example, Active Directory Domain, Enterprise, or Schema Administrators) should be closely monitored and alerted upon, as these types of accounts should not generally used to access information repositories. If the capability exists, it may be of value to monitor and alert on users that are retrieving and viewing a large number of documents and pages; this behavior may be indicative of programmatic means being used to retrieve all data within the repository. In environments with high-maturity, it may be possible to leverage User-Behavioral Analytics (UBA) platforms to detect and alert on user based anomalies.

The user access logging within Microsoft's SharePoint can be configured to report access to certain pages and documents. The user user access logging within Atlassian's Confluence can also be configured to report access to certain pages and documents through AccessLogFilter. Additional log storage and analysis infrastructure will likely be required for more robust detection capabilities.

# Mitigation

To mitigate adversary access to information repositories for collection:

* Develop and publish policies that define acceptable information to be stored
* Appropriate implementation of access control mechanisms that include both authentication and appropriate authorization
* Enforce the principle of least-privilege
* Periodic privilege review of accounts
* Mitigate access to Valid Accounts that may be used to access repositories

# References

* [Microsoft SharePoint Logging](https://support.office.com/en-us/article/configure-audit-settings-for-a-site-collection-a9920c97-38c0-44f2-8bcb-4cf1e2ae22d2)
* [Atlassian Confluence Logging](https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-enable-user-access-logging-182943.html)


# Platforms

* Linux 

* Windows 

* macOS

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

The “OopsIE” trojan, a malware affiliated with the OilRig threat group, has undergone developments to improve its obfuscation and anti-detection capabilities. Palo Alto detected the trojan being distributed in an OilRig campaign via spearphishing emails in July 2018 targeting government entities in the Middle East. The Arabic-language emails referenced a business training program, and was distributed to an email user group rather than individual addresses.

The OopsIE trojan performed a series of virtual machine and sandbox checks upon infection, and exited without initiating if these were detected; a tactic designed to hinder automated analysis of malware samples. The majority of checks have been observed in other malware samples, but a less common process was a check for the presence of a CPU fan whose absence would indicate the presence of a virtual environment. The trojan was also observed checking the time zone of the device, and only functioning if set to time zones matching the following: Arabic Daylight Time (UTC+3), Arab Daylight Time (UTC+3), Arabian Daylight Time (UTC+4), Middle East Daylight Time (UTC+2), and Iran Daylight Time (UTC+3.5).

Assessment: The time zone detection process suggested a more targeted attack against specific geographies. Other than improvements in anti-detection, there were no notable changes in the functionality of the newest iteration of OopsIE compared to older versions. The anti-sandbox checks conducted by OopsIE aimed to detect physical processes to determine the presence of a digital environment. The techniques used have all been demonstrated by other malware developers; this does not necessarily indicate a collaboration between malware developers, but more likely an effort by OilRig to emulate the successes of other threat actors for the benefit of their own campaigns. The persistence of OilRig’s activities to date suggest continued attacks against entities in the Middle East in the next six months are highly likely, with additional improvements to their malware variants for obfuscation purposes also considered likely.

Source evaluation: Palo Alto is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

Online sports gaming website DraftKings was reportedly subjected to two DDoS attacks on the 07 Aug 2018 and 08 Aug 2018. The first attack caused no reported disruption, the second included a three-fold increase in requests per second resulting in the website being taken offline for around 26 minutes.

DraftKings has attributed the DDoS attacks to 36 different IP addresses, with the majority located throughout the United States. DraftKings has filed court documents seeking to compel seven different internet service providers, hosts and networking companies to release logs that would assist in identifying ten individuals suspected of responsibility for the attack.

Assessment: The two DDoS attacks were launched in quick succession, though only one was reported to have caused disruption and degradation of service to the DraftKings website. The court documents seek to ascertain the identities of individuals suspected of involvement. The attacks occurred shortly after DraftKings launched its sports-betting service on the 06 Aug 2018; the timing therefore appears to have been conducted to deliberately coincide with his event. Without knowing the motive, it is not possible to ascertain whether additional attacks will be forthcoming. Denial of service attacks can be conducted as a means to disguise other malicious activities, such as data breaches. There was no indication this type of activity was conducted on this occasion, with the primary intent seemingly to cause disruption to the DraftKings website.

Source evaluation: There was insufficient reporting to assess the reliability of these sources, the information provided was possibly true.

Further sources:
hxxps://www.theregister[.]co[.]uk/2018/08/31/draftkings\_ddos\_suspects/
hxxp://www.bostonherald[.]com/business/business\_markets/2018/09/draftkings\_hit\_by\_cyberattack\_ahead\_of\_nfl\_season\_kickoff

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 05 September 2018, ZDNet reported on recent FIN6 activity targeting the retail sector in the US and Europe; the specific targets within this sector are unknown. A newly identified and financially motivated campaign targeting point of sale systems was observed by IBM X-Force IRIS, where 90% of attacks followed previously known attack vectors associated to FIN6 (see incident 8219574). The total frequency of attacks observed for this new campaign was not disclosed at the time of writing.

Previously limited to the GRABNEW and TRINITY malware, an increase in sophisticated tactics and techniques have been attributed to FIN6 activity. The threat group now utilize the MetaSploit framework and the Windows Management Instrumentation Command (WMIC) to remotely automate the execution of malicious PowerShell commands and scripts. Used in conjunction with XSL files, WMIC can be used to execute a multi-stage infection chain to covertly exfiltrate POS data (see incident 44076961). The campaign used executable file attachments that are delivered via phishing emails and contains malware payloads such as Passview; this malware hosts a keylogger, a backdoor for persistence and a file browser for exfiltrating data.

Assessment: Considering the frequency of attacks and increase in attack capabilities, this is likely a sophisticated campaign. Even-though the tools used by FIN6 are simple and open-sourced, their sophistication is the ability to bypass authentication covertly and persist within a system. The use of WMIC and the MetaSploit framework is likely to increase the successfulness of attacks; alongside the use of the popular phishing email attack vector. The source of the phishing target list is unknown at the time of writing; however, FIN6 have previously used remote system discovery tools for exploit reconnaissance and is likely to be used in this campaign to establish vulnerabilities and map networks. FIN6 will highly likely continue this campaign targeting the retail sector in the near future (within three months) due to the profitability of payment card and financial credential data.

Source Evaluation: ZDNet is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.

Other Sources: hxxps://www.zdnet[.]com/article/windows-utility-used-by-malware-in-new-information-theft-campaigns/
objects.name: Newly observed FIN6 campaign targets point of sale systems within the retail sector (Digital Shadows Id: 44106906)

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 04 Sep 2018, IBM X-Force researchers announced a newly discovered trojan dubbed "CamuBot", which has been used to steal the credentials of Brazilian banking customers since at least August 2018. Unlike previously reported financial malware variants, CamuBot is reportedly unique in using an attack vector which combines social engineering components with visible installation, disguising itself as a security application which victims are instructed to install by a human operator pretending to be a bank employee.

After an initial stage of reconnaissance, during which attackers identify businesses that bank with a specific major financial institution, CamuBot operators reportedly initiate a phone call with victims and instruct them to access a provided URL to check whether their security module is up to date. When the validity of the check returns a negative response, victims are instructed to install a "new" security module which uses the spoofed bank's brand imagery. Upon completion the victims are directed to a phishing site requesting they log into their banking accounts, thereby unknowingly sending their credentials to the malware operator. If a victim's credentials alone do not permit an account takeover, CamuBot bypasses two-factor authentication using an incorporated interceptor through which the attacker remotely captures one-time passwords sent to the victim's machine.

Assessment: At the time of writing CamuBot had not been sighted targeting entities in geographies outside of Brazil, and had not been attributed to a specific threat actor. The customizability of CamuBot, in addition to its remote two-factor authentication interceptor, makes it a sophisticated tool that will likely become sought-after by threat actors in wider geographies in the next six to 12 months.

Source evaluation: IBM X-Force is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.
objects.name: New "CamuBot" trojan targets Brazilian banking customers (Digital Shadows Id: 44101836)

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

The SANS Internet Storm Center has reported that thousands of 3D printers are exposed online and vulnerable to remote attacks. Threat actors can potentially steal sensitive trade data sent to printers, upload their own print files and have them printed, and access webcams embedded on printers. A Shodan query on the 30 Aug 2018 located more than 3,700 printer interfaces exposed online, the majority of which were based in the United States.

The printers are exposed through OctoPrint, a web interface for 3D printers that can be used to remotely monitor and control devices. The interface permits the download of objects in G-code format, which an attacker could manipulate if the administrator has not enabled certain access controls or authentication mechanisms.

Assessment: Threat actors are likely to target this type of vulnerability to conduct commercial espionage and steal sensitive intellectual property sent to 3D printers. The exposure poses a particular risk to organizations using 3D printers for manufacturing. Companies that use 3D printers should ensure that access control features are enabled to prevent printers from being publicly exposed, and thus vulnerable to exploitation. There was no indication this attack vector had been exploited in the wild to date.

Source evaluation: Security Affairs is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.

Additional sources: hxxps://isc.sans[.]edu/forums/diary/3D+Printers+in+The+Wild+What+Can+Go+Wrong/24044/
objects.name: Threat actors can access 3D printers exposed online for sabotage and espionage attacks (Digital Shadows Id: 44084508)

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 04 Sep 2018, security researchers reported that over 7,500 routers manufactured by software company MikroTik were actively being exploited. Using known vulnerability CVE-2018-14847, the unknown threat actors modified victims’ router settings to forward email traffic from SMTP, POP3 and IMAP as well as file transfer protocol (FTP) data to attacker-controlled IP addresses. 1,628 compromised devices were identified in Russia, with a further 637 in Iran and 615 in Brazil.

The same threat actor was observed exploiting the same vulnerability on MikroTik routers to (unsuccessfully) infect victims with the cryptocurrency mining script Coinhive in early August 2018 (see incident 40575574). Additionally, a total of 239,000 routers were observed to have the SOCKS4 proxy enabled, which could allow for further malicious activity.

Assessment: Although a patch addressing the vulnerability was released by MikroTik in April 2018, many organizations may be slow to prioritize the patching of affected devices. Security researchers state over 370,000 MikroTik routers worldwide are still susceptible to the vulnerability, the majority of which in Russia and Brazil. The unknown threat actor’s intentions could not be determined at the time of writing, however, the volume of devices targeted suggest further malicious activity is likely. Users are advised to apply the latest security patches on all vulnerable devices.

Source evaluation: Qihoo 360 Netlab is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.
objects.name: 7,500 compromised MikroTik routers observed forwarding traffic to attackers (Digital Shadows Id: 44085520)

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 30 Aug 2018, Forbes reported an espionage campaign conducted by a newly-identified APT group named "WindShift". Since 2016, WindShift reportedly used malware dubbed "WindTale" and "WindTape" which leveraged a vulnerability specific to Apple Mac devices to target individuals that worked in government and critical infrastructure in the Middle East. The specific nations targeted were not identified in the reporting, but were alleged to be members of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) region which consists of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the UAE, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman. WindShift remained unattributed or affiliated with a specific nation-state at the time of writing, and their exact motives were unconfirmed.

According to researchers at the cyber security company DarkMatter, the attack vector consisted of spearphishing emails containing a malicious hyperlink. Interaction with the link resulted in the attempted installation of a .ZIP file, following which a malicious script would leverage an as-yet-unidentified vulnerability in Apple Mac devices resulting in the Safari browser automatically unzipping the malicious file. Next it would attempt to launch a "custom URL scheme"; a non-malicious function used by developers to initiate certain processes within apps. The custom URL requested the launch of the malware from the attacker's command and control (C2) domain. WindTale and WindTape are both capable of capturing screenshots and trawling through documents on the compromised device, as well as potentially on the device's network.

Assessment: The techniques used by this threat actor appears to be uniquely suited to Apple devices, as the same method would allegedly have failed on Windows devices due to the presence of additional security functions. This suggests the campaign was highly targeted. A successful attack relies upon user interaction with the hyperlink in the phishing email, and also acceptance of two pop-up prompts asking for the user to accept the custom URL and download a file. However, the content of these prompts can be altered by the attacker in order to trick the user. There is minimal information available regarding the vulnerability exploited in this attack; Apple claims to have rectified the issue without providing details of remediation steps taken. At the time of writing, the number and identity of the victims affected had not been publicly disclosed. According to DarkMatter, WindShift APT group are linked to previous sophisticated espionage attacks, but cannot yet be attributed to a nation-state; a wide variety of different nations have political and economic interests in the region.

Source Evaluation: Forbes is usually reliable and the information provided was probably true.

Additional sources:
hxxps://gsec.hitb[.]org/materials/sg2018/D1%20COMMSEC%20-%20In%20the%20Trails%20of%20WINDSHIFT%20APT%20-%20Taha%20Karim.pdf
objects.name: Middle East targeted by newly identified cyber espionage group "WindShift" (Digital Shadows Id: 44067644)

On 06 Mar 2017 MacKeeper and CSOOnline reported on a data breach affecting a suspected spam operation by a purported marketing company known as River City Media (RCM). Security researcher Chris Vickery reportedly discovered data belonging to RCM in Jan 2017 after their Rsync backups were improperly configured. By using a variation of the Slowloris Denial of Service (DoS) attack tool, RCM were purportedly able to overwhelm email servers and force them to process bulk emails, resulting in one million spam emails being sent a day. MacKeeper also claimed that the company had gathered a database of 1.4 billion email accounts, full names, IP addresses, and some physical addresses. Most of the personal records were reportedly collected by a process called co-registration, whereby personal information is shared with a third-party after a user signed-up for a service or product online. The revelations have already reportedly been used to blacklist RCM’s entire infrastructure. While these blacklisting efforts will almost certainly hinder RCM’s operations, it was assessed as highly likely that spam activity, on the whole, will continue for the foreseeable future – particularly given the lucrative nature of spam services as revealed by RCM’s accounting information. The data was found to contain almost 1.4 billion records including email and IP addresses, names and physical addresses, all of which was used as part of an enormous spam operation. Once de-duplicated, there were 393 million unique email addresses within the exposed data.
objects.name: River City Media Spam List (Digital Shadows Id: 16648770)

In July 2015, the Qatar National Bank suffered a data breach which exposed 15k documents totalling 1.4GB and detailing more than 100k accounts with passwords and PINs. The incident was made public some 9 months later in April 2016 when the documents appeared publicly on a file sharing site. Analysis of the breached data suggests the attack began by exploiting a SQL injection flaw in the bank's website.

This data has been secured from "HaveIBeenpwned" repository, therefore, although the incident does not display the exposed passwords, these have been confirmed as compromised for each corresponding email listed.

The published data included lists of emails including the sender's name and email address as well as the contents of the email as well, often with signatures including other personal data.

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 04 Sep 2018, an unknown threat actor compromised the Google Chrome extension of the cloud storage service Mega. A malicious version 3.39.4 extension was uploaded to the Chrome webstore which, upon update/installation, asked for elevated permissions to read and change website data. The malicious extension was reportedly live for four hours and affected an unknown number of users. The attacker designed the extension to exfiltrate credentials for popular websites such as Amazon, GitHub, Google, Outlook and MyEtherWallet to a server located in Ukraine. Interestingly, the extension did not appear to target data pertaining to Mega services.

Although it was not disclosed how the attacker gained access to Mega’s Chrome webstore account, the company notes that all Google Chrome extensions are signed automatically upon upload — unlike other browsers such as Firefox, which require extensions to be signed and hosted by the developer. This meant that once access to Mega’s account was established, the threat actor could upload the unsigned malicious extension and it would be signed by Google. At the time of writing, the official Mega application has been removed from the Google Chrome webstore altogether.

Assessment: Google Chrome’s automatic updating of extensions means that any users active during the period in which an extension is compromised are at risk. This makes browser webstores an attractive initial attack vector for threat actors, and extensions have been exploited by threat actors in several campaigns throughout 2018. In July 2018, an unknown threat actor similarly compromised the Chrome webstore account for the free Hola virtual private network (VPN) extension for a period of five hours (see incident 37727025). The malicious extension sought to harvest credentials by redirecting victims to a phishing page targeting users of the cryptocurrency manager MyEtherWallet — a site also targeted by the malicious Mega extension. Malicious Chrome extensions have also been used to hijack cryptocurrency transactions and gain remote access to infected machines (see incidents 32831310 and 34553604). Attackers are likely to continue exploiting browser extensions in the mid-term (between three months and one year). Potentially affected users should change their passwords and ensure susceptible accounts are protected via additional security measures such as multi-factor authentication (MFA).

Source evaluation: There was insufficient reporting to judge the reliability of Mega, the information provided was possibly true.
objects.name: Mega cloud storage Chrome extension compromised by unknown attacker (Digital Shadows Id: 44128177)

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 31 Aug 2018, a teenager in Hertfordshire, United Kingdom was arrested and pleaded guilty to three counts of making hoax email bomb threats. Using the name “Apophis Squad”, the individual was responsible for emailing over 20,000 schools and universities with bomb threats in March 2018, forcing approximately 400 schools to be evacuated. The emails were allegedly spoofed to appear as if they were sent from VeltPvP, a network for the popular video game Minecraft. Although arrested soon after, the individual reportedly broke the terms of his bail by continuing to access Internet-connected devices. In August 2018 they contacted authorities at San Francisco International Airport claiming an inbound United Airlines flight from London Heathrow had been hijacked. The charged is due to appear in court on 21 Sep 2018.

Assessment: Apophis Squad has primarily carried out denial of service (DoS) attacks against organizations in the United Kingdom and United States (for example, see incident 36395312). The group has also targeted schools with violent, threatening hoax emails and offers DoS-for-hire services on their website. They are very active on social media via their Twitter account “@apophissquadv2”, posting claims of successful attacks and mocking law enforcement agencies. However, their Twitter account has had no public activity since 30 Aug 2018, the day before this arrest.

The incidents attributed to the individual were also discussed by the group on social media, whom appear generally unafraid to brag about their accomplishments. For example, on 09 Aug 2018, a screenshot of a flight tracker was posted, with Apophis Squad claiming to have “grounded” United Airlines 949. Their account also contains multiple references to VeltPvP, the same Minecraft network whose email domain was spoofed to send hoax bomb threats.

An update on the group’s Twitter account on 07 Aug 2018 suggests this individual was not the sole member or operator of Apophis Squad; five others were listed as belonging to the group. The arrest is likely to have an impact on the group’s activity and capabilities in the immediate future (in the next few days), as suggested by their decreased presence online since this arrest. It is not known if the group will continue coordinating attacks in the mid-term (between three months and one year), though given their displayed public defiance against law enforcement agencies it should be considered a realistic possibility.

Source evaluation: Infosecurity Magazine is considered usually reliable, the information provided was probably true.
objects.name: Alleged member of Apophis Squad arrested over email bomb hoax (Digital Shadows Id: 44115396)

On 11 May 2017, it was reported that Edmodo, a popular online education platform, had been a victim of a data breach. The data contained usernames, email addresses, and hashed and salted passwords reportedly encrypted using the bcrypt algorithm. The data was originally advertised for sale in Apr 2017, but appears to have become freely available on 24 May 2017 when posted to a clear web database sharing forum. The data set provided contains over 43 million unique email addresses, despite the claim of 77 million records alleged on the original advertisement.

In late 2016, a huge list of email address and password pairs appeared in a "combo list" referred to as "Exploit.In". The list contained 593 million unique email addresses, many with multiple different passwords hacked from various online systems. The list was broadly circulated and used for "credential stuffing", that is attackers employ it in an attempt to identify other online systems where the account owner had reused their password. For detailed background on this incident, read https://www.troyhunt.com/password-reuse-credential-stuffing-and-another-1-billion-records-in-have-i-been-pwned "Password reuse, credential stuffing and another billion records in Have I been pwned."

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

On 18 May 2016 the Twitter account @wormws, which was associated with the grey/black hat actor known as w0rm, posted a tweet containing a link to a downloadable zip file. The tweet claimed that the file contained 100 million sets of user data for the cloud storage site Dropbox, but did not specify the purported contents of each individual record. However, on 02 Jun 2016 Krebs on Security (hxxp://krebsonsecurity[.]com/2016/06/dropbox-smeared-in-week-of-megabreaches) reported that the file linked in this tweet actually contained data obtained from Tumblr in 2013. This dataset was previously identified as for sale on the dark web criminal marketplace The Real Deal, but this is the first example we have identified of a freely available set of the data.

On 12 May 2016, a post was published on the official Tumblr website indicating that the company suffered a data breach in early 2013. The post stated that in 2013 a third party had gained access to a set of Tumblr user email addresses with salted and hashed passwords, prior to the acquisition of Tumblr by Yahoo. The statement by Tumblr claimed that there was no reason to believe the information was used to access Tumblr accounts and stated that users would be required to set new passwords as a security precaution. The number of users affected by the breach was not revealed in the Tumblr statement. On 30 May 2016, however, Motherboard reported that the security researcher Troy Hunt had claimed 65 million users were affected. Hunt allegedly obtained a copy of the stolen data which he identified as containing 65,469,298 unique emails and passwords stored as salted SHA1 hashes. Hunt also claimed that data was later put up for sale on a Dark Web market website. Motherboard suggested an actor known as Peace had claimed to have access to the data and was selling it on the Dark Web marketplace The Real Deal. The dataset has been added to haveibeenpwned[.]com and users can conduct email searches to determine if their data was exposed.

Assessment: We have downloaded and partially examined the dataset posted by w0rm and have determined that it contained 73 million records which may contain duplicates, each of which included an email address and salted SHA1 password hash. Although the number of records is not totally consistent with previous reporting (Troy Hunt identified the number at around 65 million unique records), this is possibly due to duplicates. The content of the data is assessed to be consistent with previous reporting of the contents data obtained from Tumblr in 2013. Furthermore, a random sample of email addresses from this dataset were tested and all were found to be present in the 2013 Tumblr breach dataset hosted on haveibeenpwned[.]com. It is therefore assessed as likely that the dataset posted by w0rm is the same set of Tumblr user data which was compromised in 2013 and offered for sale on the Real Deal in May 2016.
objects.name: Report of data leak from Tumblr users (Digital Shadows Id: 10691469)

objects.body:
View the incident report on Digital Shadows here.

Security researchers identified a malware campaign using multiple Windows tools within its attack chain. The malware was not specifically named, although it is detected by Symantec as SONAR.MSHta!g2. SONAR had multiple payloads including a password harvester, keylogger, backdoor and a cryptocurrency miner. The malware was delivered via phishing emails which contained either a malicious link or attachment; if the user executes the malicious file, a Windows Management Instrumentation Command-line (WMIC) command is run, downloading an XSL file. The XSL file contained JavaScript which would be executed using mshta.exe. WMIC, XSL files and mshta.exe are all legitimately used within Windows operating systems, typically by administrators to manage the operating environment.

Assessment: The use of legitimate Windows-based utilities during a malware infection campaign is not a new technique (see PowerShell incidents 43661439, 42977502, 41982934), and typically is successful, as the malicious activity can pose as legitimate. WMIC specifically has been observed in August 2018, as a variant of the jRAT remote access trojan used it to increase obfuscation (see incident 42160107). While it is not known if this specific malware variant presents a risk, as no targeting information was reported, malicious actors’ use of legitimate Windows administrator utilities has been increasing, as Symantec reported a 661-percent increase between 2017 and 2018 (hxxps://www.symantec[.]com/blogs/threat-intelligence/powershell-threats-grow-further-and-operate-plain-sight) This trend is likely to continue throughout the second half of 2018.

Source evaluation: Symentec is considered usually reliable and an accurate source of information.
objects.name: Ongoing use of legitimate Windows utilities in malware campaigns (Digital Shadows Id: 44076961)

肚脑虫组织（APT-C-35, 后文统称肚脑虫组织），又称Donot，是一个针对克什米尔地区相关国家的政府机构等领域进行网络间谍活动，以窃取敏感信息为主的攻击组织。该组织于2017年3月由360追日团队首次曝光，随后有数个国内外安全团队持续追踪并披露该组织的最新攻击活动。被曝光的的攻击活动都是针对PC端进行，攻击最早在2016年4月，至今活跃，攻击方式主要采用鱼叉邮件进行攻击。
